channel.title: gOS?
channel.description:
Was just randomly browsing and found [url=http://www.thinkgos.com/]this[/url] today. Its another Linux distro thats based off Ubuntu, but its completely emerged with...google apps? :confused: I read up a bit more on it and its actually gaining popularity pretty fast
The first release surprised the industry with its sudden popularity, due in part due to its use on the Everex Green gPC, which sold at Wal-Mart (for awhile, anyway, no longer is) for only $200.
Apparently a lot of the normal apps have been replaced with google substitutes
The third release continues the gOS love affair with Google by embracing the search giant's Gadgets -- small, graphically rich, widget-like applications that can be quickly downloaded and added to the desktop. gOS 3.0 also comes with Google Desktop as an alternative to Tracker, Google Picasa as an alternative to F-Spot, and Google Earth, which "complements the existing link to Google Maps," says the company. In addition, Google Documents, Calendar, and Mail now launch in Mozilla Prism windows.
Then I looked up what Mozilla "Prism" was..
Prism is a new application from mozilla that splits web applications out of their browser and runs them directly on the gOS desktop. Included: Google Mail, Google Calendar, Google Documents, and YouTube.
Sounds really cool! read more about it [url=http://desktoplinux.com/news/NS2665924172.html]here[/url] or [url=http://www.theregister.co.uk/2008/08/25/gos_review/]here[/url] and you can download it [url=http://www.thinkgos.com/dgadgets.php]here[/url] I might just download it to try it out. [img]http://desktoplinux.com/files/misc/gos_gadgets_picasa.jpg[/img]

item.title: gOS?
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:4, topic:239545”][quote author=PeterMan link=topic=315826.msg2508835#msg2508835 date=1225161277]
I have one question, since I have never used Linux before.

Do I have to already own/have installed Linux for gOS to work?

No, it is free and as long as you own a computer you can install linux.

As to this thread, it looks like a very stripped down version of kubuntu, which for some people would be good, but I’d rather have the whole thing.
[/quote][/quote]

Its stripped ubuntu, and its worthless, ubuntu boots works, this dosent.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: October 28, 2008, 02:49:27 pm[/size][hr]https://wiki.ubuntu.com/DerivativeTeam/Derivatives/gOS

Read full topic

item.title: gOS?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled, post:14, topic:239545”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=315826.msg2509436#msg2509436 date=1225205621]
As to this thread, it looks like a very stripped down version of kubuntu, which for some people would be good, but I’d rather have the whole thing.
[/quote]
Looks more like Gnome than KDE…
I might try this out in VirtualBox later if I’m bored, it seems somewhat decent.[/quote]

It’s actually neither, it is ‘Enlightenment’ or something. You can install that in ubuntu/kubuntu too if you want. I meant the apps were a watered down version.

Read full topic

[quote=“sanga282, post:6, topic:239545”][quote author=PeterMan link=topic=315826.msg2509442#msg2509442 date=1225206030]

I have one question, since I have never used Linux before.

Do I have to already own/have installed Linux for gOS to work?

No, it is free and as long as you own a computer you can install linux.

As to this thread, it looks like a very stripped down version of kubuntu, which for some people would be good, but I’d rather have the whole thing.

Thanks for the answer, I’m gonna download this, and use it on my old laptop or my old desktop
[/quote]
test it in a virtaul machine, you might install it and think it is the most awful thing you’ve ever seen[/quote]

Hey, thanks for the hint. Got a link incase I don’t find anything on google?

EDIT: I failed at googling a virtual machine. Link pl0x
Would be really appriciated, rewarded with lots of hugglez!

item.title: gOS?
item.dc:creator: @llib llib
item.description:
@llib wrote:

Was just randomly browsing and found this today.

Its another Linux distro thats based off Ubuntu, but its completely emerged with…google apps?

I read up a bit more on it and its actually gaining popularity pretty fast

The first release surprised the industry with its sudden popularity, due in part due to its use on the Everex Green gPC, which sold at Wal-Mart (for awhile, anyway, no longer is) for only $200.

Apparently a lot of the normal apps have been replaced with google substitutes

The third release continues the gOS love affair with Google by embracing the search giant's Gadgets -- small, graphically rich, widget-like applications that can be quickly downloaded and added to the desktop. gOS 3.0 also comes with Google Desktop as an alternative to Tracker, Google Picasa as an alternative to F-Spot, and Google Earth, which "complements the existing link to Google Maps," says the company. In addition, Google Documents, Calendar, and Mail now launch in Mozilla Prism windows.

Then I looked up what Mozilla “Prism” was…

Prism is a new application from mozilla that splits web applications out of their browser and runs them directly on the gOS desktop. Included: Google Mail, Google Calendar, Google Documents, and YouTube.
Sounds really cool!

read more about it here or here and you can download it here

I might just download it to try it out.

Read full topic
